test.name: Test 1

kw.name: Connect To Database
kw.doc: Loads the DB API 2.0 module given `dbapiModuleName` then uses it to connect to the database using `dbName`, `dbUsername`, and `dbPassword`.
kw.msg: Connecting using : pymysql.connect(db=demo_database, user=root, passwd=***, host=localhost, port=3306, charset=None)

kw.name: Query
kw.arg: Select name, surname from demo1 where age < 7;
kw.doc: Uses the input `selectStatement` to query for the values that will be returned as a list of tuples. Set optional input `sansTran` to True to run command without an explicit transaction commit or rollback. Set optional input `returnAsDict` to True to return values as a list of dictionaries.
kw.msg: Executing : Query | Select name, surname from demo1 where age < 7;
${result} = (('Lion', 'Goodwin'),)

kw.name: Log
kw.doc: Logs the given message with the given level.
kw.msg: people who yonger than 7 (('Lion', 'Goodwin'),)

kw.name: Check If Not Exists In Database
kw.msg: Executing : Check If Not Exists In Database | Select * from demo1 where salary = 0;
Executing : Query | Select * from demo1 where salary = 0;
Expected to have have no rows from 'Select * from demo1 where salary = 0;', but got some rows: ((4, 'Sergio', 'Trulle', 95, 0), (8, 'Violetta', 'White', 7, 0))

kw.name: Disconnect From Database
kw.doc: Disconnects from the database. By default it's not an error if there was no open database connection - suitable for usage as a teardown. However you can enforce it using the `error_if_no_connection` parameter.
kw.msg: Executing : Disconnect From Database

test.status: Expected to have have no rows from 'Select * from demo1 where salary = 0;', but got some rows: ((4, 'Sergio', 'Trulle', 95, 0), (8, 'Violetta', 'White', 7, 0))

kw.name: Connect To Database
kw.doc: Loads the DB API 2.0 module given `dbapiModuleName` then uses it to connect to the database using `dbName`, `dbUsername`, and `dbPassword`.
kw.msg: Connecting using : pymysql.connect(db=demo_database, user=root, passwd=***, host=localhost, port=3306, charset=None)

kw.name: Delete All Rows From Table
kw.doc: Delete all the rows within a given table. Set optional input `sansTran` to True to run command without an explicit transaction commit or rollback.
kw.msg: Executing : Delete All Rows From Table | DELETE FROM demo1

kw.name: Row Count Is 0
kw.doc: Check if any rows are returned from the submitted `selectStatement`. If there are, then this will throw an AssertionError. Set optional input `sansTran` to True to run command without an explicit transaction commit or rollback. The default error message can be overridden with the `msg` argument.
kw.msg: Executing : Row Count Is 0 | selectStatement
Executing : Row Count | Select * from demo1;

kw.name: Disconnect From Database
kw.doc: Disconnects from the database. By default it's not an error if there was no open database connection - suitable for usage as a teardown. However you can enforce it using the `error_if_no_connection` parameter.
kw.msg: Executing : Disconnect From Database

kw.name: Connect To Database Using Custom Params
kw.doc: Loads the DB API 2.0 module given `dbapiModuleName` then uses it to connect to the database using the map string `db_connect_string` (parsed as a list of named arguments).
kw.msg: Executing : Connect To Database Using Custom Params : pymysql.connect(db_api_2.connect(database='demo_database', user='root', password=***, host='localhost'))

kw.name: Execute Sql Script
kw.doc: Executes the content of the `sqlScriptFileName` as SQL commands. Useful for setting the database to a known state before running your tests, or clearing out your test data after running each a test. Set optional input `sansTran` to True to run command without an explicit transaction commit or rollback.
kw.msg: Executing : Execute SQL Script | ./data_for_demo1.sql
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (1, 'Jon', 'Do', 21, 10000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (2, 'Ivan', 'Smith', 24, 12000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (3, 'Marry', 'Popins', 17, 8000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (4, 'Sergio', 'Trulle', 95, 0)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (5, 'Berta', 'Rassel', 34, 20000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (6, 'Trune', 'Urroro', 45, 30000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (7, 'Agneta', 'Bartovna', 60, 15000)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (8, 'Violetta', 'White', 7, 0)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (9, 'Lion', 'Goodwin', 2, 99999)
Executing statement from script file: INSERT INTO demo1 (id, name, surname, age, salary) VALUES (10, 'Karetto', 'Jovanny', 50, 50000)
${result} = None

kw.name: Log
kw.doc: Logs the given message with the given level.
kw.msg: None

kw.name: Row Count Is Equal To X
kw.doc: Check if the number of rows returned from `selectStatement` is equal to the value submitted. If not, then this will throw an AssertionError. Set optional input `sansTran` to True to run command without an explicit transaction commit or rollback. The default error message can be overridden with the `msg` argument.
kw.msg: Executing : Row Count Is Equal To X | Select * from demo1; | 10
Executing : Row Count | Select * from demo1;

kw.name: Disconnect From Database
kw.doc: Disconnects from the database. By default it's not an error if there was no open database connection - suitable for usage as a teardown. However you can enforce it using the `error_if_no_connection` parameter.
kw.msg: Executing : Disconnect From Database
